The QComponent Class


The QComponent class in QueFlowJS allows to create and manage reusable components with reactive data and dynamic rendering.



Syntax: 
        QComponent
        (
        selector
         : string, {
 
          stylesheet
         : object, 

          data
         : object, 

          template
         : function | string, 

          created
         : function, 

          run : function
})


Creating a Component

To create a QComponent, you need to provide the following:

  1. Selector:
    A string or DOM element representing the target element where the component will be mounted.
  2. Options: An object containing the following properties:
    1. data:
      An object or primitive value representing the initial data for your component.
    2. template:
      A string or a function that returns a JSX/HTML string representing the component's structure and content.
    3. stylesheet:
      (optional) An object containing CSS styles for component-specific styling.
    4. strict:
      (optional) A boolean indicating whether to use innerHTML or innerText for non-parent elements. Defaults to true, using innerText


Example:





Reactive Data and Updates

The data property of a QComponent is a reactive signal. Any changes to the data will automatically trigger a re-render of the component, updating the DOM accordingly.


Example:





Freezing and Unfreezing Components

You can prevent a component from further updates/re-rendering by using the freeze() method:

          myComponent.freeze();

To re-enable updates, use the unfreeze() method:

          myComponent.unfreeze();


Component Scoped Stylesheets

The stylesheet option in the QComponent constructor allows you to define component-specific styles. The styles will only apply to the component's element and its descendants.




Note

For scoped styles to work, the target element of your component must have a valid id attribute.
